thread.title: Citi Australia launches Citi Mobile Challenge Asia-Pacific
thread.title_full: Citi Australia launches Citi Mobile Challenge Asia-Pacific | afr.com

author: Rose Powell
title: Citi Australia launches Citi Mobile Challenge Asia-Pacific
text:
CitiBank IT chief Linda Duncombe: "Looking forward to working with the local start-up scene." Michele Mossop Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Rose Powell Citibank's Australian operation will launch a new financial technology accelerator program, which will include a developers challenge to connect the global investment bank with new tech talent and disruptive ideas.
Citi will host an Asia-Pacific digital acceleration program in November that will see Australian developers competing against others in Hong Kong, Singapore and Bangalore for a share in $100,000, mentoring and the opportunity to integrate their product or services into Citi's operations.
Citi Australia's managing director of customer franchise, Linda Duncombe, said the program was designed to ensure Citi was tapping into emerging trends.
"Our core competency is banking and we're learning very quickly that the best part of innovating is about having the right partnerships, and we're looking forward to working with the local start-up scene to do that," Ms Duncombe said.
The program is focused on mobile banking, and Ms Duncombe said Citi was particularly interested in software solutions that made banking easier to do online.
The Citi Mobile Challenge has been run in other regions, including the United States and Latin America as well as a combined region that includes Europe, the UK and the Middle East, known as EMEA. The program gives developers access to data, technology APIs and insights from Citi's network.
Aussie success More than 750 companies entered the most recent EMEA challenge, only to beaten by an Australian founded company for customer introduction and onboarding Avoka Transact.
 "We found that working with Avoka was cheaper and more effective than anything we had tried internally," Ms Duncombe said.
While it may be cheaper to partner with a rising technology company, the program does not come cheap. Along with the cost of running a major, four-country event, Citi has also allocated funds to invest in potential partnerships with promising companies.
"It costs us a lot of money to put on something like this," Ms Duncombe said. "It's a major investment for us and we've set aside money in next year's budget for this event to ensure we can follow through."
Alongside its program, Citi also runs a series of fintech accelerator programs in the United States and Israel. Ms Duncombe said it was keen to invest further in the local start-up community after the program, although the shape of that commitment was yet to be determined.
The head of Citi's Israeli innovation centre, Lyron Wahrman, said the accelerator program had partnered with several of the companies going through their program.
"The accelerator was about extending our reach in the sector," Mr Wahrman said. "When there are synergies, we try to incorporate their solutions in our work. This happens pretty often but it doesn't have to: some just take part in the program and grow."
Australia's financial technology start-up scene has flourished over the last three years, with more than 800 people registered across a range of fintech community groups.
There are two targeted accelerator programs already active, AWI's financial technology accelerator and Tyro's fintech hub; another, Stone & Chalk, is due to announce its first intake this year.
